Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Characterization and mechanistic modeling of methane production, flow and ebullition from fine-grained sediments in a temperate lake
Award.AbstractNarration:
Methane is a potent greenhouse gas, but its effects on Earth?s climate remain poorly constrained, in part due to uncertainties in global methane fluxes to the atmosphere. An important source of atmospheric methane is the methane generated in organic-rich sediments underlying surface water bodies, including lakes, wetlands, and the ocean. The fraction of the methane released from the sediments that bypasses dissolution in the water column and reaches the atmosphere may contribute significantly to global warming, and this fraction depends critically on the mode and spatiotemporal characteristics of free-gas venting from the underlying sediments. Advances in understanding methane ebullition require better mechanistic models of the hydrologic processes in the sediments, better understanding of the parameters and driving forces controlling gas production and accumulation, bubble growth, conduit evolution and persistence, vent spacing, ebullition rates, and the episodicity, frequency, and duration of venting events. The goal of this project is to develop quantitative models of methane production, migration and release of methane from fine-grained sediments. The mathematical and computational models will be constrained by and tested against comprehensive field and laboratory experiments that will characterize the rate, duration, and frequency of methane venting, bubble rise and dissolution of methane in the water column, the morphology and spacing of gas vent conduits in sediments, the distribution of gas in shallow sediments relative to its likely locus of production, and methane production metabolic pathways and rates in the sediments. Field data to inform the numerical models will be acquired from an area of known methane venting from fine-grained sediments in the central basin of Upper Mystic Lake, a dimictic kettle lake near Boston, Massachusetts.

Methane is an important greenhouse gas, nominally 20 times more potent than carbon dioxide. There is currently a focused effort from the scientific community to better constrain methane fluxes and improve our understanding of the feedbacks between methane sources and climate change. In many settings, methane is released not directly to the atmosphere, but to bodies of water from underlying sediments where the methane is generated by biological activity, or transported from deeper sources of thermogenic origin. The mechanisms controlling methane venting from sediments are not well understood. In this project, we seek to advance current understanding of methane transport and release from fine-grained sediments. If successful, our findings will lay the groundwork for integrated modeling to constrain the global methane release from lakes, wetlands, estuaries and shallow continental margins.

Intellectual Merit

 

Methane is an important greenhouse gas, nominally 20 times more potent than carbon dioxide. There is currently a focused effort from the scientific community to better constrain methane fluxes and improve our understanding of the feedbacks between methane sources and climate change. In many settings, methane is released not directly to the atmosphere, but to the water column of lakes and other bodies of water from underlying sediments where the methane is generated by biological activity, or transported from deeper sources of thermogenic origin. Such water bodies appear to contribute significantly to the atmospheric methane burden, and could potentially become more important under warmer climatic conditions. However, the mechanisms controlling methane venting from sediments are not well understood, especially with regard to the spatial and temporal distribution of venting sites. Understanding this venting process is a key to knowing what portion of the methane produced in sediments ultimately reaches the atmosphere.

 

As a result of this project, we have advanced our understanding of the spatiotemporal dynamics of methane venting from organic-rich lake sediments, and have shown that gas vents—the dominant pathways for methane emission—are ephemeral, challenging previous assumptions that such conduits, once formed, would be persistent. Our analysis shows that vents are frequently forming and closing off throughout the homogeneous sediments that make up the seep field in the lake’s deep basin. This finding, grounded on direct high-resolution field measurements over months-long deployment, challenges the idea that sediment conduits, once established, will continue to be the preferential locus for future methane emissions. Another key and complementary accomplishment of the project is the direct physical measurement of both bubble fluxes and sizes, including the design and implementation of novel instrumentation for long-term in-situ measurement of the above quantities. We anticipate that our results will excite the interest of a broad readership in the geosciences and climate science, and will invigorate recent discussions in the literature. Our data-driven mechanistic description of methane venting from organic-rich sediments should be incorporated into efforts towards the understanding, monitoring and accounting of global methane fluxes from lakes, wetlands, estuaries and shallow ocean sediments.

 

This grant has supported in part the PhD research of three graduate students at MIT, and involved three other undergraduate students assisting in the research. Each of the graduate students involved in the project has published scientific papers in peer-reviewed journals, and presented their work at international conferences, notably the Fall Meeting of the American Geophysical Union. These opportunities have allowed them to disseminate their work, and to network with other academics in the broad areas of Hydrology and Biogeosciences.

 

The findings from this research have led directly or contributed to 6 peer-reviewed journal publications, 12 conference papers/abstracts, 2 PhD dissertations (in progress) and 1 MS thesis.
